description.text: One of my USB sticks had a cover that broke open, so I made this! It's a from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17656, cleaned up, modified slightly, and smoothed in Blender. There's a hole in the top half of the model for fitting the innards of a USB stick, and the bottom half slips over the USB plug to form a cap. The USB stick sticks out slightly in the back, but I didn't want to slide the top half of the model forward because of stability reasons. I might make another version with the USB stick positioned slightly forward - I didn't do that originally because the walls were a bit thin in that position, but I'm sure with some modifications it could be made to work.

Print the top and bottom halves separately, with support. I used 20% infill and 0.2 mm layers with 0.8mm thick walls and top/bottom in Cura. Carefully remove supports, paying attention around the arms and back. I actually broke off one of the blades on the arm while I was cleaning up. Oops!
Slide the USB stick innards into the top half of the model. My USB stick fit perfectly, and I used a bit of molten plastic to seal it in there (just let the extruder run at a higher-than normal temperature, use tweezers to grab molten plastic, and wedge it in the hole). Superglue should work fine as well, just make sure the whole thing fits together properly first!
If you have a larger USB stick, you may have to cut away at the sides a bit. If yours is smaller, make sure to keep it centered properly, or else the top half of the model won't slide into the bottom correctly!
A pretty neat model to go next to my Thor, and it's also functional!

title: 18650 Multi-Purpose Housing - 2 Cell version
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Seems like every 18650 holder / housing / case i've come across on Thingiverse didn't quite fit the bill. Some where for niche applications, some were not meant to be used for anything beyond storage, and some didn't seem to allocate the extra space for contacts.

So, i popped into fusion360, and this is the end result.

It's a 2-cell holder with the following features:

  • mounting holes, spaced 20mm from either end, and 9.75mm from center spine
  • Cavities for contacts on either end
  • Wiggle room, for ease of installation and removal of the cells.
  • Extended Notches at each terminal point to accommodate multiple contact styles, or soldered wire.
  • Side cutout for ease of use, because my fingers are fatter than an exacto blade.
  • Strap / Tie down brackets, because, you may want to strap this to a squirrel some time in the future. shrugs

Hope it's useful. Always open for design ideas, and suggestions.

As always, if you printed it out, feel free to throw up a photo or two.

Image of Printed part done with 0.2mm layer height, 3 top and bottom solid layers. 20% infil, with a 0.4mm nozzle. Took about 2 hours to print off.

This is for those tiny crimp on dupont connectors that fit inside the plugs that plug into the RAMPS board. Tolerances on this are TIGHT! don't feel bad if you can't print a working one. This isn't going to crush the connector tight but it is enough to get those little tabs to start folding in the right way so you can squish it flat with some needle nose pliers. You can also give the crimper a smack with a hammer to close the jaws tighter after you've closed it as much as you can by hand. Feel free to mix this up and make a stronger one if you like. You can get the uncrimped connectors and plugs at places like banggood.com for about $7. The real tool is available there too for $17. Print it solid. With some swearing and a magnifying glass you can make your own custom plugs!

description.text:
Loved this stand so I had to remix it for my Fitbit Ionic. Been through alot of plastic getting it right. I tried to get too ambitious and make it have fancy cable routing, but it proved impossible to get the USB cable to go where I wanted it to go. Finally settled on matching the original and this one works well.

v3c is the prototype the pictures came from. I haven't printed v5 but It's an improvement with better angle and slot position to better center the watch and make cable insertion easier.

It's a little tight inserted the USB, but it will go with some pressure. You may need to use some kind of pick(I did) to get the usb cable tip to turn, but once it does you should be good.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

15%

Notes:

1.2mm walls

Modeling Steps.
  • Inserted a cube to surround the entire internal cutout area of Apple Watch.
  • Subtracted hand to leave the cutout area.
  • I trimmed off all of the pieces from this I didn't need so I could add my own cutout for fitbit charger slot.
  • Same technique(much simpler this time) to get the cutout of the Ionic charge stand.
  • Merged the two cutout's together with some tuning of angle/position.
  • Subtracted the final cutout object from NaturalThing to get final result.

title: Adafruit Trinket Pro 5v enclosure for my led drum lights project (v2)

description.text:
I used https://www.tinkercad.com to make the enclosure and cover.

It fits the https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0778G64QZ/ breadboard with the Trinket Pro 5v really well.

This was for a project to build animated lights/LEDs for my daughter's drum set. See the full project on my github page: https://github.com/morridm/drumlights. It's a work in progress.

I made a parts shopping list on amazon for the components I used here: http://a.co/bAPFz74

This is the current version of the enclosure I use to house all the components.

  1. https://vimeo.com/259484616
  2. https://vimeo.com/250054557

My first version didn't have a potentiometer or a buttom. My new version has a potentiometer to control piezo sensitivity and a button to control animation modes. My updated version uses the Adafruit Trinket Pro instead of the Trinket; since I needed more pins and power for the pot and button.

title: An alternative, non threaded crank and worm for the $3.47 3D Scanner

description.text:
I was having trouble working with the crank assembly for the $3.47 3D Scanner that datac printed/created, so I went into Blender, and made a square joint because my threads were printing out too big for the crank to connect to the worm gear. I increased the infill to 40% to make my print more solid. You may have to shave the crank's square part to fit into the worm's slot, I did a little, but afterwards, it worked great. I do not take any credit for this, as datac worked hard to make this project work and all I did was 5 minutes of moving shapes around in Blender.

I failed to mention that I'm not exactly very experienced with 3d printing, so I'm sure that people will find an easier way to make this work, but for any of us who can't seem to get this to print right, I'm sure this would help. If I happen to be breaking any rules, please let me know and I will take this down.

Edit: You'll probably want to have some kind of adhesive to keep the worm and crank held together.

Monoprice Maker Select Ultimate

remixed_from.author: StudioForge
remixed_from.title: StudioForge's E3D Hot End TronXYx5s Mount

title: StudioForge's TronXYx5s Quick Disconnect Head System

description.text:
This is a continuation to my original remix E3D attachment for the Tronxy x5s that came from the E3D v6 Bowden X-carriage mount Prusa i3 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:547706) by Tech2C (http://www.thingiverse.com/Tech2C) and the Tronxy X5S Filament Shroud (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2664058) by SummersideGuy (http://www.thingiverse.com/SummersideGuy). Again big thanks to both of them for their parts.

Here are some videos that show and tell the laser attachment, hot end attachment, and power quick disconnects, https://youtu.be/Q6IN8r4F4tU https://youtu.be/kFiK8UQrJcE

This next evolution really got me to where I wanted to go, a way to quickly change X carriage attachments with little or no tools. I wanted to do this once I saw this on YouTube, https://youtu.be/Q1KTGC1Dbz0, from Jake's Workshop (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCNLgThgmIe5BcQ-bbB0CxoA). Also while troubleshooting Z movement while X was traveling I found that being able to attache a dial indicator was helpful. So here is what is included in this initial release:

  • Quick Disconnect Anchor
  • E3D / E3D Lite Hot End attachment with Tronxy X5S Filament Shroud mount point
  • E3D / E3D Lite Hot End attachment without an filament fan mount point (someone might want it)
  • Laser attachment for a 33mm x 33mm x 65mm 500mw 405NM focusing blue purple laser module tube diode (Amazon / Aliepress)
  • Dial Indicator attachment for a 1" travel machinist's dial indicator (Harbor Freight)
  • Modified Anchor to attach to Tronxy X5S frame for storage of attachments

Printer:

Tronxy X5S

Resolution:

.1 - .2

Infill:

80+

Notes:

Now I am printing most of my projects with a raft to counter the Z movement while traveling in X. The wheels on the X carriage, and probably the Y, are not round so I get a good amount of movement that I have to compensate for, see my facebook thread https://www.facebook.com/groups/169728600253557/permalink/218247182068365/?hc_location=ufi. If you get good first layers on your rig then rafts are up to you. I also don't get very good bridging out of my setup so I printed these with supports to get some good flat surfaces so again if you get good bridging then supports are optional.

Final steps

I tried my best to make this to use extra parts from the kit so you wouldn't need to make a trip to the store. You might need to get some stuff still though. The kit didn't really have any extra T-nuts but ImShogun (https://www.thingiverse.com/ImShogun) made up these m3 and m4 T-nuts (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:951730). You will use the m4 and kit included 20mm x 4mm screws to mount the racks to the printer frame.

The E3D hot end attachment uses 20mm x 3mm screws to hold the clamp in place.

Any attachment can use the same 20mm x 3mm screw to hold it more securely to the anchor in conjunction with the magnet or to hold the attachment completely without a magnet.

After printing you will need to make some minor adjustments more than likely. If you used a raft or supports you will want to take a sharp knife, I used an #11 blade to trim off any extra spots. Careful they are sharp. Sand paper etc. will help also to get a good fit. You might need to clear out the hole for the screw head on the anchor so the screw will fit in nicely. Once the parts slide together nicely you can remove the stock hot end but leave the mounting studs. The anchor will fit right on to them and secure the anchor down with some 8mm x 3mm screws (should be extras from the X5S kit). If you want to follow what I did exactly then you ditch the stock hot end cooling shroud and filament cooling fan. Use the stock hot end cooling fan for the Tronxy X5S Filament Shroud. You will also need to come up with some way to quick disconnect the power and thermistor wires. I used some scavenged USB A connectors male and female for the low amperage connections of the thermistor and filament fan / Laser signal wires. It feels wrong when you start cutting wires, but make sure you go slow and be precise and you shouldn't have and issue. If you let the magic smoke out of any of your components don't blame me, you should have found an electrical engineer friend before you messed with it.

The circle divot is there thanks to Otto Renner (https://www.facebook.com/otto.renner.16?fref=gc&dti=169728600253557) for suggesting the use of magnets. I happen to have some 3/8 in. Neodymium Rare-Earth Magnet Discs that I picked up from Home Depot and the work great seeing as the have a hole in the center that is the perfect size to allow a 3mm screw to pass through. This is one of those items you will need to run to the store for, sorry. Use some superglue to place one in the anchor, then for each of the attachments make sure you get the polarity correct by first placing the attachment magnet on the anchor magnet and mark a side with a sharpie then glue the attachment magnet into the attachment sharpie side down.

For the laser you will use the filament cooling fan power to control the laser power state, if you follow Jake's Workshop like I did. You might find that the printer will error if it is not getting a signal from the thermistor. To "trick" the printer into thinking that the thermistor is connected you can measure the resistance the thermistor is producing at room temperature by using a digital multimeter then use a corresponding resistor. I made a USB resistor module for mine and I used a 110K ohm resistor.

I think everything else is self explanatory but make sure you re-adjust your end stops for your limit switches. I had to add some extra to the Y truck to trigger the Y limit switch.

author: GBDave

description.text:
Polyominoes (aka Pentominoes) date to antiquity and became popular circa 1907. They were first seriously discussed by Solomon W. Golomb. an American Mathematician and Electrical Engineer in 1953 and were later featured by Arthur C. Clarke in a Science Fiction novel, Imperial Earth, in 1974.

Herewith are presented the 12 unique pieces which comprise ALL of the possible shapes made by combining FIVE squares into a single piece such that each square contacts an adjacent square with the full length of a side. These 12 shapes are unique in that they are not duplicated by any rotation or mirroring.

As a mental exercise, you might try drawing them on graph paper before you examine the shapes too closely here. All 12 shapes are given as individual .stl files plus a single file which can print all of them at once, if you're confident in your printer.

You will also find the Box here... https://www.thingiverse.com/make:460310
It fits all of the pieces in a neat 3 x 4 x 5 box. How they fit is left for you to solve.

PUZZLE

Each of the 12 pieces is 5 cubes in size or a total of 60 cubes (5 x 12). They may be arranged in perfect rectangles of 6 x 10, 5 x 12, 4 x 15, and 3 x 20. There are over 900,000 possible solutions in total but only TWO for the 3 x 20 rectangular shape. Have fun!

Printing Notes...
These were originally designed using 10mm cubes but in order to allow for interlocking and nesting, they were reduced to 9.75mm cubes and longer pieces at 19.5, 29.5 and 39.5mm lengths using a few 10mm recesses. All of this allows for easy nesting.
CAUTION... These parts will only print well if your X and Y axis values are well calibrated and equal.

title: SCALEPRINT LINKA COMPATIBLE DOUBLE SIDED BRICK TILE MOULD 00/HO
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Today have something special for you Linka users a printed mould for making double sided brick tiles for those walls you want to see from both sides.

The mould has a 2 degree draft angle to help get the plaster part out of the mould.
I make the plaster like a paste then fill both halves of the mould and then clamp them together, giving a a number of taps on the bench so all the plaster flows together.
If you have a mould release it will help get the plaster part out of the mould.
When cured using a knife separate the 2 halves, and carefully working along the open end lift and remove the part from the second half.

This should also print on an FDM printer with a 0.2 nozzle as the mortar lines are 0.4 mm wide

Printer:

WANHOA D7

Resolution:

0.025 Z height

Notes:

I printed this mould on a Wanhoa D7 in Monocure Rapid Clear Resin which is a non-flexible resin as that is all that I have. If you have a flexible resin it would be easier.

This should also print on an FDM printer with a 0.2 nozzle as the mortar lines are 0.4 mm wide

title: Gatchaman G-Force Battle of The Planets Phoenix

description.text:
This is a remix of Gentle Giant's Phoenix airplane from the 1970s Japanese anime, "Gatchaman" (aka Science Ninja Team Gatchaman). It was known as "Battle of the Planets" (aka G-Force) in the USA. If you want to know more about this Japanese anime check out the Wikipedia article. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_Ninja_Team_Gatchaman

I took the model and split the file into three individual parts using MeshMixer in order to print a larger model that can be glued together after printing. When printing the middle section of this model I suggest using support and a raft. When removing the rafts be careful doing so around the three small fins at the back and top of the model. Even at the size I printed my model they were still quite delicate to handle.

Once I printed all three pieces I glued them together with Goop brand multi-purpose adhesive and let the adhesive cure overnight.

Many thanks to GentleGiant for the creation of this 3D model!

description.text:
This is a simple note paper holder for your desktop. I designed it for 92mm x 92mm paper blocks which seem to be the standard in stores where I live, but the geometry of the holder is simple enough that you can easily scale it in XY and/or Z direction to fit your desired paper size and amount.

For your convenience, I provide two versions of the model:

  • A "full model" which can be printed in one piece if your printer and time allows. This will look nicer than the segmented model, but will take longer to print.
  • A "segmented model" comprised of a base plate and four pylons. These must be glued to the base plate, but this version will take less time to print.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40% rectlinear

Notes:

Printed with PLA.

For the segmented model, you'll need to print one base plate and four copies of the pylon.

Scale the model in XY direction to accomodate paper sizes other than 92x92mm, or scale it in Z direction to allow for a higher paper stack.

Assembly

If you printed the full model, it's ready to use as is.

The segmented model needs to be assembled by glueing the four pylons to the base plate in the matching recesses in the corners.

I suggest using a glue designed for model making, such as UHU Hart or similar.

This is a dual color model of HPV's (Human Papillomavirus) capsid structure.

I imported Educator's HPV model .stl into a program called Meshmixer. In this program, I edited the design using the 'plane cut' and 'separate shells' editing tools. I differentiated each of the protruding regions of the capsid as different .stl's, and then combined all these separate .stls into 1 .stl.

At this point I had two .stls that I was working with in Meshmixer (one was the combined .stl of the protrusions and the other was the icosahedral). I exported/saved them both as two separate .stls.

I then opened both .stls in Cura (Ultimaker's 3D printing program/platform). Subsequently, I marked the floating protrusions .stl to be printed by extruder 2. Then I selected both models, right clicked, and selected 'merge models'. Both models then combined to make the original HPV virus structure, however, different regions now differentiated for dual color printing.

These files were used in the planning stages of a ultraportable telescope build. These files should not be used for direct printing of said telescope, since many of the details have not been included. Furthermore, during the build process, many of the parts were modified in order that the build can be completed to spec. Nevertheless, use these files as aids for building the scope. Especially consider lengthening the box, in order that the secondary mirror assembly can be kept in the box.

If you use these files, please attribute it to me (Cyrus Beh)

Works best against backlighting.
The images show a proper (4.5mm) and a misaligned (3.5mm) measurement.

Notes:

All bottom and top edges are chamfered, so you don't need to worry about a too thick first layer.

This is a fairly straight forward Iphone to spotting scope adapter.

This was sized to fit an Iphone 8 and a Bariska spotting scope. The diameter of the eyepiece was roughly 1.525 inches.

I made the inner diameter of the sleeve 1.55 to allow a bit of room.

The final print was a little tight on the scope and on the phone requiring a bit of sanding to get the fit just right for both. I think this was due to the general crankiness of my printer (A8s can bo so passive agressive), You may want to scale it up a couple of percent just in case. It's a lot easier to snug the fit up than it is to loosen it up.

I can't get a picture of the adapter in use because my only camera is the phone but I think it's pretty straight forward.

The center slot is so you can add a band around the middle to double secure the phone. Mine is pretty snug so I left the band off but I was standing in one place waiting for Big birds that don't like their picture taken to show up.

Enjoy

You should rotate the stl because i'm lazy.

This is an original ray gun side-arm I've drawn up.

It has provisions for LEDS and wiring. It has 23 5mm holes set up for lights. Example in video below.

6 go in each of the 3 light rings
3 go in the barrel
and 3 go in the back "control panel"

There is a slot on the opposite side of the control panel for a button cell battery holder. This doubles as a greeblie on the side of the gun and easy battery replacement.

Print the light ring 3 times in transparent material
Print the barrel in transparent as well. Everything else can be solid. I used "natural" pla for my lighted parts. Then later paint in the parts that you don't want to illuminate. I'll post more pictures as I get mine painted.

The trigger I mounted by using a chunk of PLA strand, sliding through the holes in the chassis, through the hole in the trigger, and then glued the strand to the sides of the chassis. I used a momentary spring loaded button behind them to activate the lighting and it springs the trigger forward again.

The 1/4" holes in the side of the forward body and chassis are for adding a piece of 1/4" tubing for some more detail. i used some red plastic fuel line.

title: Miter Rail For Ryobi Table Saw

description.text:
Let's face it, the miter slots on the Ryobi Table saw are bad, other than that, great saw for the price. This is a group of files that that help improve the miter track. First off is the miter rails, there is one with the arrow and holes already laid out for the miter gauge that comes with the saw and another that is solid. On my saw these slide easily with no wiggle. There is also a handle that has an inset for a #8 nut.

My print bed can only produce 8 inches in length. I like a longer rail so the rails will dovetail together.

If you need the design to make a custom rail, here is a onShape link.

The text reads, "SEMPER IN DOCTRINA, SEMPER FACIS", which is Latin for, "Always learning, Always Making".

author: PaladinDG

description.text:
I had 2 out of 3 attempts at the featured "Lego" balloon boat leak air so much that you couldn't blow up the balloon (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2783012). So searched for other models and found this one (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2347730). Big thanks to the original designer as the shape of the Hull is awesome!

I was also inspired by a previous remix that split it into more pieces (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2452678), but had problems printing it with the hull being very thin on the sides towards the rear. I also wanted to mount the balloon more towards the rear to move weight and help balance the boat and keep the jet in the water, so used Tinkercad to create this remix.

I print the "Jet" at .12 100% infill to prevent any leaks and they always come out air tight, the "Deck" at .2 30%, and the "Hull" at .28 100% infill, rotated 180 degrees "upside down" and it did not require supports on the several that I made.

To assemble, I put the Jet thru the hole in the Hull and the use the Deck to get in the right spot, then "tack" it to the bottom of the Hull with a drop of superglue. After that dries, I pull off the Deck and put a bead of superglue on each side of the Jet where it touches the bottom of the Hull, then also a big drop ("runny" superglue works better than gel) on the top of the Jet where it goes thru the inside of the and tip it to the side so it runs down to the bottom to create a seal. Then do another drop tipping it the other direction to get both sides. Then I put a bead of superglue around the top edge of the Hull and drop the deck into position and let that dry. Then I put a good fillet of superglue around the inside of the balloon neck where the top of the Jet comes and let that run down to seal there, let it dry and do it again to be sure it is air tight there.

I made this to join some wooden dowels together.
This fits a 1 3/8" dowel which fits snugly but I made this in metric so it should fit a 35mm dowel as well but it hasn't been tested.

title: FBI Mail Robot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a roughly 1/7 scale functional model of the mail robot introduced in season 2 of the TV show The Americans. https://uproxx.files.wordpress.com/2017/06/mail-robot.gif
I never planned to make "scale models of office robots from spy shows on FX" into a series, but here we are. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:920194
I had always planned on catching up on The Americans, but didn't get around to it until last winter ahead of season 5. This project has actually been in the works for the entire past year. I thought that building it around existing electronics would make it easier than the Milton project, so I ordered the absolute cheapest line following robot kit I could find on eBay. It arrived very quickly but the package was missing literally 90% of the advertised components. The seller promised to send the rest, but after a few months of waiting for that to never arrive, I decided to put the project off until this winter. Eventually I ordered another kit which was still extremely cheap but also arrived complete. After assembling, I took measurements and built a rough 3D model of the line following robot, which then allowed me to decide on a scale for the mail robot shell. Initially I wasn't planning to build something quite so big again, but making the mail robot occupy roughly the same footprint as the line following robot would require the proportions to be quite radically altered. I then scaled it up to 1/6 to fit over the line following robot, before stepping down to 1/7 to better fit my printer. The only real deviation I had to make from the shape of the TV mail robot was adding an extra step under the shelves because of the height of the battery pack.

You can see the finished bot in action here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2As6K4clplc

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

5%

Notes:

Print one of each part, except for the pins (4), ends and lenses (2 each). For the shelves, you can either print the version that's all one piece or the version separated into flat slot-fit parts (you'll need 4 shelves and 3 vertical dividers) depending on what you think your printer can handle. Only the bottom and the lenses really need support.
I printed everything but the lenses in ABS, and due to the size of the parts there were a few cracks to fix. I really don't love the color either. I think the ideal material would be an almond PET, but this was not available when I was shopping for plastic for this project.

Assembly

This project is built around an existing line-following robot kit. This is the one I ended up using: https://www.ebay.com/itm/252786280689 It's very cheap, and was easy enough to assemble even without any real instructions. I imagine it may be a knockoff of some name-brand kit. I added some wire to the red LEDs (8 inches from the front, 12 for the rear) so they could be mounted in the right place on the mail robot instead of flush to the board of the line follower.
You'll also need a pair of AA batteries, some thin clear plastic for the sides, and maybe some paper to dress the shelves.

The bottom, top, and ends fit together with built-in pegs and sockets. The "mid" plate fits between the "bottom" and the "base" using the 4 pegs. I glued together the top, bottom, ends and shelves, but left the base as snap-fit. I had to open up the vertical holes in the ends with a drill bit to fit the LEDs through. It's easier to push the LED wires through those holes with the mid plate and base loose, but remember to route the wiring through the big hole in the middle of those. I hot glued the wires in place and the lenses to the LEDs to keep them from slipping back down.

The base has some locating tabs to fit it onto the board of the line-following robot, but it's not an incredibly tight fit. The LED wires should be left long enough so that you can access the line-following robot to change batteries or adjust the potentiometers.

I made the doors out of clear thin packaging plastic (probably PET?). I sort of eyeballed it, taking measurements from the printed model instead of the computer design. You'll want to leave little 1x2mm tabs on one end for the hinges. The "mail" inside is just cut-up paper scraps glued to the shelves.

I wasn't expecting to find blueprints online for this, but of course they did have to make blueprints for the production. This shot was at least good for figuring out the exact size and scale: https://twitter.com/FBImailrobot/status/600388213572788225

title: Delta Jet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is one of my older planes - its obsolete and doesn't fly that well compared to my newer designs! check out my other models here on thingiverse and more models and books I wrote on 3D Design and 3D Printing here at threedsy.com

This plane flies good if tuned well, but cannot be hand launched easily. A better derivative can be found at thing 28266, here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28266 Known working instructions: Print the wings and fuselage halves using ABS. .30 layer height (or close) , 2 perimeters, and 2 solid layers, .30 line fill. use a 0 degree angle for the solid fill on the wing, or you will have warping problems. Print the launcher with the same layers, but with 3 perimeters, 2 solid layers, and .35 line fill. Assemble the two halves onto the wing from each side, with the smooth side up. Use super glue to stick the halves together when you are satisfied that the airplane is symmetrical and that the wings are perpendicular to the fuselage. Put on a nice strong rubber band, and fly! The control surfaces can be cut free to change the flight charateristics, and a small hole is provided to accomodate wrapping copper wire or solder for weight. 2" of 1mm solder seemed about right. Other materials and layer heights may work as well, please post your results!

Assembly Instructions

Print out two of every part. The middle piece and rod pieces are symmetric, while the 'side' has a front and back piece which each need to be printed twice

Put together the two middle pieces using two M5x8 screws and two M5 nuts
Put together the two rod pieces using two M5x8 screws and two M5 nuts
Put together the two sets of front and back pieces to form the left and right holders using three M5x8 screws and three M5 nuts each.

Mount to the rail using two M5x6 + two M5 T-nut per assembled part.
Parts are designed so they can be twisted onto the rail and then screwed in.

It should look like the picture when it's assembled.

title: MP Mini Delta LED PSU mount

description.text:
I wanted to get a variable voltage PSU for my mini instead of the underpowered 5a stock brick, and have a proper power switch. This allows the addition of a 12v 10a LED driver style PSU. My model is a JC Power JC-120-12, but anything with a cross section of about 46x37mm will fit

The bottom bracket screws into the stock screw locations under the back tower and one new hole you need to drill into the frame, and accepts a standard IEC320 C14 power socket and switch. There are recesses on the inside to catch a M3 square nut. The top bracket screws into another hole you need to drill. With the two piece nature it can accommodate supplies of varying lengths and there is a slot left open so you can access the voltage adjustment potentiometer. You can cut a length of the stock power cord to wire up the PSU so you don't have to solder and wires onto the control board.

Note that you cannot access the stock spool holder slots with this mod, though if you want you could install it on one of the two front towers though it would look odd.

Both parts are printable on your Mini Delta

YMMV but I can now maintain 240c/120c given enough time to stabilize. Due to how the firmware controls the heaters, to print effectively at high bed temps you should add a delay into your gcode files after preheating but before the print starts in order for everything to stabilize. Otherwise your bed may get to 120c, drop to 60c while the extruder heats, then only be back up to 80c when it actually starts printing. Adding glass and or insulation to the bed to increase thermal mass and reduce heat loss will minimize this effect.

description.text:
This is a fairly straight forward LED light designed to use the flat 48 bulb units that are all over ebay.

I made this up to replace all the hot - power hungry - and not particularly bright 12 volt lights in my Pull behind camper and my house boat (which is a camper on pontoons) as well as lighting for the boat dock and all my other off grid buildings.

These use the flat led panels that are delightfully cheap and bright. If you google
"White-48-SMD-COB-LED-T10-4W-12V" or some variation thereof you will find they are pretty ubiquitous.

Close observation (or casual observation for that matter) will show that I put the mounting holes too close to the corners so I had to notch the corners of the lens instead of drilling proper holes. I've fixed this in the model but I haven't printed a second one yet. You know those breathalyzer things that they put in peoples cars. I think I need a version of that for my computer but instead of alcohol it detects caffeine levels. Too low and you can't get on cad. Although, the alcohol version seems logical too. Not for me, mind you. Just for people with online dating profiles. Or Facebook .. . .

author: joergkrause

title: Laser Cut 5 SD Cards Storage Case

description.text:
Laser Cut and Engraved SD Card organizer storage box. Holds 5 SD Cards, looks great.

https://youtu.be/uoN8YEIVxNo

Assembly requires some acrylic adhesive (Weld-on #16).

  • Cut main SD Card slot holder from 1/8" acrylic (card_slots.dxf)
  • Cut main case body from 1/4" acrylic (enclosure.dxf)
  • Cut Card Slot Holder bottom from 1/16" acrylic (card_bottom.dxf)
  • Cut two covers from 1/16" acrylic (enclosure_covers.dxf)

Clean parts with alcohol prior to gluing.

  • First glue Card Slot Holder bottom to Card Slot Holder. Makes sure edges are even.
  • Now glue one of the main covers to main body. Use Card Slot Holder as a guide, but be careful not to glue it accidentally to edges.
  • Check fit and finally glue second main cover to main body.

Engraving (optinal):

  • Align complete enclosure in laser and engrave with text of your choice or included "engraving.dxf" file. Use "cut" setting at low power and high speed to "scratch" engraving on acrylic. You don't want to cut it thru, but also grooves need to be deep enough for paint to stick.
  • Rub some white acrylic pain into engraving, let it dry a little and wipe it off.
  • Repeat until enough paint filled the engraving. Wipe again with slightly moistened rug.

author: weaponizedemoticon

title: More Vintage Style Party Lights for Patio, RV, or Camper

description.text:
Inspired by vintage blow molded lights, and user "mxfaiman" version of the vintage lights.

I tried to capture some other shapes evocative of other blow molded patio lights that I was so used to seeing at camp grounds when I was young, and I will add more here as I get through them. These can use almost any kind of string light with this adapter. It can fit regular C7 bulbs, and can also fit the 40mm, globe style bulbs that use the same socket as C7 (It looks like these are known as G40 bulbs). Keep the wattage low or get LED versions of C7 so the covers don't melt.

Print the "shell" with no top, no infill, and 2 or 3 walls/shells.

Tips:
Print the Ice Cream scoop with 0 top and 0 bottom layers.
Print the Ice Cream Cone with 0 bottom and 2 or 3 top layers.
The windmill blades have to be printed flat and glued on afterward. Or modify them with a hole that will mount on the base.
I think you get the idea how this works.

The "adapter" can be printed at 10% infill. The adapter has an outer diameter of 70mm. Superglue it on top of the shell once you have both done.

Making your own shells is simple enough, just get a model in about the right proportions (100mm tall, with a top roughly 70x70mm), print it hollow with no top, and superglue the adapter on top.

description.text:
I was looking for an dial indicator mount for my Monoprice Maker Select v2 (Wanhao Duplicator i3 clone) that was 1) inline with the print nozzle and 2) designed with strength and minimal material usage in mind. I wasn't able to find one that worked for me. So, here's my version of a dial indicator mount for a Wanhao Duplicator i3.

I designed the mount specificly for a Harbor Freight Dial Indicator, but this mount will work for any dial indicator with a 9.5mm stem.

Prepare the clamping mechansim by taping the smaller hole on the clamp tab using a M4x07 tap. The original design called for a M4x10mm thumb screw. However, an alternate configuration (4mm bolt and wing nut) was used as a result of availability.

To install the dial indicator mount, tap the two mounting holes using an M3x0.5 tap. Then use two M3x8mm bolts to attach the mount to the carriage. Once mounted, the dial indicator can be slid down into pace and secured by tightening thumb screw or wing nut. To remove, simply loosen the thumb screw or wing nut and slide the dial indicator up, out
of the mount.

Monoprice MakerSelect V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

For maximum strength orientation, print using the orientation associated with the STL file. You should be able to just download and print without having to reorient the part in your slicer.

I printed using a floor/ceiling and wall thicknesses at 1.2mm, 3 times the width of my nozzle diameter (0.4mm). Shouldn't need much more strength.

It's designed so you can paint the engine bay first before assembling and get some nice detail there. Enjoy!

3/11/2018 edit I replaced the Parts 1 and 2 file as I printed it out and it had a bunch of air pockets that caused weak walls and such. Also the details for the engine exhausts is too small so it came out a hot mess. I've filled the air pockets to be solid and redesigned the exhausts to have thicker walls so should print out better. As I print these files out myself, I'll be correcting them as I see errors. Do comment here if you are printing them out and let me know errors you may encounter. Fly casual!

description.text:
Converted Snap Rover to Arduino Obstacle Avoiding Automatic Roaming Rover.

Have also attached the working Arduino sketch file.
Download library for motor shield at: https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-motor-shield/library-install

Items needed for this project:

  1. Snap Rover - https://www.ebay.com/i/122959754766?rt=nc
  2. Arduino Uno Board -
  3. Arduino Motor Shield
  4. Parallax Standard Servo
  5. HC-SR04 Ultrasonic Sonar

  6. Two adjustable voltage regulators (one set to 5V to power Arduino and second to 9v to power motor shield.

    https://www.ebay.com/itm/10pcs-Mini360-3A-DC-Voltage-Step-Down-Power-Converter-Buck-Module-3-3V-5V-9V-12V/132416658988?epid=1402279667&hash=item1ed4a5de2c:g:mLMAAOSwRlhapFRp

Per sketch use motor output 1 and 4 on the motor shield.
Sonar connects to 5VDC and Ground and Trig to A4 and Echo to A5 (Arduino pins)
Servo connects to (servo 2) on the shield.

Battery mount is designed for XT60 connector and toggle switch 12x20mm socket (similar type found on computer power supply boxes) Running this setup off 3S LiPo battery.

My motor shield for some reason did not have 5V to power the servo and sonar only 3.5V on 5V pins, so I connected them straight to the output of 5V voltage regulator which powers the Arduino.

Have fun printing.. Don't forget to like if you find it interesting.

title: Improved Centrifugal Suparmagnum for Wanhao Duplicator 6
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Since my customized fan bracket for Reflector's SuperMagnum fan duct failed, I decided to look into other options. The SuperMagnum duct itself is a sound design, but the centrifugal add-on as a separate piece leaves the blower fan without enough clearance. My solution was to redesign the main air box and integrate the fan mount directly into the duct.

I have not yet printed this design for testing, so use at your own risk, but it should work.
It uses the same 40mm centrifugal blower as the original SuperMagnum duct, but has a lip inside the air box for the fan to sit on, and mount for a single 3mm screw.

Obviously this is printed with the bracket opening pointed up, and supports turned touching buildplate only.

This is not the cleanest mod. I used Tinkercad to mod this, and so had a limited tool set. If it works out, I will try to clean it up in a real cad program at some point.

title: US Mail Box Auto Flag
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Auto Flag for your mail box.
This will automatically raise the flag when you mail man opens the mail box.
It fits standard US mail box with flag. (see Photo)
3D print from ABS for longevity in the weather.
You will require some additional hardware.

  1. A spring from an old pen (5 mm od x 30 mm long).
  2. Two x 6 mm bolts that are 20 mm long (to replace the production bolts).
  3. Some 1.5 mm nylon ripcord.

There are 3 parts to this design,
MailBoxDoor
This is secured to the outside of the door using one of the 6 mm bolts Print is same color as the door.

MailBoxInner
This goes against the mail box and locates in the existing flag holes.

MailBoxOuter
This houses the return spring and fits over the MailBoxInner part.
The spring is used to retract the ripcord when the door is closed.
The ripcord connects this part to the MailBoxDoor part, and it raises the flag when rotated.
Adjust Flag bolt to create a resistance on the flag so that it stays up. (less is best)

title: Tales of Berseria: Laphicet's Compass
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is Laphicet's compass from Tales of Berseria, split into sections for printing on a standard 200mmx200mm bed printer. This is a functional gimbal compass: it is self-levelling and has a needle that points north!

Most of the pieces have small slots in them for 9 gauge metal wire, which I used small segments of to assist in the assembly process (in addition to E6000 and epoxy as needed).

The needle has slots for two neodymium magnets, which is how it works as a functional compass needle. The magnets I used were these: https://www.magnet4sale.com/n52-5-16x1-neodymium-rare-earth-cylindrical-magnet/. I recommend printing the needle with the lightest settings possible, even if it means extra postprocessing work, since that will make it function better as a compass needle. I balanced the needle itself on a small aluminum point. I put a very small amount of masking tape under one side of the needle to balance it for northern hemisphere usage.

I used McMaster-Carr parts 6391K153 (x2), 6391K155 (x2), and 1570K22 for assembly. Or, in simpler terms, a keyed shaft (which I cut with a dremel into four pieces) and bearings. I had to sand down the shaft a fair bit in order to get it to rotate smoothly in the bearings, so I kinda suspect I bought the wrong shaft, but I'm not a real mechanical engineer so who knows? ;-)

I also reused a small bit of the shaft to make the aluminum pointed mount for the needle mentioned above: this is important because the mount can't be ferromagnetic, or it'll throw off the needle. I cut it to a point with my dremel, which was a long and painful process that likely would have taken 7 seconds if I had a proper tool, like a lathe.

For finishing I made use of XTC-3D, Modern Metals spray paint, Alclad Polished Brass paint, Molotow Liquid Chrome paint, Alclad Aqua Gloss sealant, and an enormous amount of sandpaper and elbow grease, as well as Liquitex acrylics for the faux-wood base.

The details are were done with spray paint and (extremely carefully applied) stencils. The compass rose itself is a separate 9.25" acrylic circle.

title: X-Carve Pen Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a pen holder for use with a CNC machine. This was designed specifically for an x-carve z carriage mount.

This design utilizes rubber bands as a "shock" system to keep pressure on the pen without damaging it or the drawing surface.

See it assembled:
https://www.instagram.com/p/BcqMK_sAjoe/?taken-by=cera.tops

See it in action:
https://www.instagram.com/p/BcqSDNlgGyn/?taken-by=cera.tops
https://www.instagram.com/p/BcrKTr1An3S/?taken-by=cera.tops
https://www.instagram.com/p/BekVIfJAlEn/?taken-by=cera.tops

604 skateboard bearings can be snapped into place in the base. These constrain the shock-carriage perpendicular to the drawing surface.

M3 bolts are used to fasten clamps to the carriage, and to screw the clamps closed around a pen.

Rubber bands (I used o-rings I had lying around) are used as a spring mechanism, connecting the carrage to the base.

title: Year of the Dog... 'Dog'
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Designed for the 'Year of the Dog' in 2018 there are two .stl's provided. One includes decorations for the Chinese year and the other is a plain... dog. Both just small and easy prints.

However, both feature a tail that will lift/drop and wag from left to right... just for fun!

The photos provided demonstrate how the tail can move up and down as well as from side to side. This requires a well set up / accurate / precise machine and a well sliced file.... but most modern machines should deal with the fine internal clearances between the moving parts with no issues.

If you run into fusing issues with the moving parts this is usually caused by the slicing app you are using, your machines inability to print precisely / accurately, or an inefficient filament cooling fan. These are the key areas to check / work on... the quick fix is to uniformly scale the model up by 5 - 10% which will increase the internal clearances so they can be freed up and move as intended.

These dogs look great printed in any colour. They will scale up okay but scaling down is likely to result in the moving parts fusing so the tail won't move as intended.

Please read the print settings information and view the images provided to help ensure you get a great result... and post images of your 'Dog' prints for other members to see.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard / 0.20mm

Infill:

2 Shells / 25% or more infill / PLA with an efficient filament fan (to minimise the chance of the moving parts fusing)

Just remove the raft...

...then gently free the tail to wag and rotating section by wiggling / applying sideways pressure and / or a rotating motion. Worst case scenario, use a craft knife to free any obviously fused areas.

If you run into fusing issues with the moving parts this is usually caused by the slicing app you are using, your machines inability to print precisely / accurately, or an inefficient filament cooling fan. These are the key areas to check / work on... the quick fix is to uniformly scale the model up by 5 - 10% which will increase the internal clearances so they can be freed up and move as intended.

title: Door Speaker Adapter for Toyota GT86/Scion FR-S/Subaru BRZ

description.text:
This is a Door Speaker Adapter for Toyota GT86/Scion FR-S/Subaru BRZ. It is a full redisign of Schankenstein´s Speaker Adapter. It also features a rainshield, which is allways very important to have. It is made for the Andrian Audio A165V and A165G speakers,

Status:

-Printed and partly tested (fitment to speaker is tested, not installed to car jet)

Note:

-Even if the position of the door speaker is less critical in case of the FT86 compared to other cars, there is still a risk to guide water, dripping down from the window slot, into the interior of the car when installing aftermarket speakers. Most OEM speakers include a rainshield, but this is often erased when aftermarket speakers are installed.

Instructions:

-Use PETG or ABS. Materials like PLA will not withstand the heat and stress of this application. Furthermore, accoustics could be affected in a negative way.
-Print with the speaker flange facing the print bed.
-Use supports. Printbed touching, 70° overhang angle.
-Print with 100% infill, but take care to really use infill and not maximum bottom layer count. (in CURA) Set bottom layer / top layer count to 3. Otherwise you might get a slow and/or a weak print.
-Make sure to use a good overlap between infill and inner wall to get a strong print.
-Use zig zac or lines as infill patern to get a strong print. Do not use concentric patern.
-Take care that there is no concentric gap inside of the print in the area of the rainshield. You might need to play arrond with lines width of the inner walls.

title: Battle Tag Ubisoft
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
These parts allow for a replacement cable to be made for the Ubisoft Battle TAG gun to the vest.

Required is the 2 printed parts (The vest can use either the side or bottom part).
Plus the following parts: (Suggest eBay Search)
2 x 4 Wires Lead 616E 4P4C RJ9 Female Socket Telephone Connector Adapter
1 x RJ9 4P4C Plug Coiled Stretchy Telephone Handsets Cable Line Bla T3S6 or similar.

Please see pictures for wiring examples, test prior to sewing to vest, and ensure that all of your upgrades follow the same pattern so they are interchangeable.

VEST:
Cut cord leaving about 10-15 cm dangling outside of the vest, mark and cut a small hole in the vest for the plug, feed the cable end back into the vest and out of the new hole, by making a loop outside of the vest, then pull through. Do not push back into the vest before it is out of the hole. If using the side plug style insert the plug then solder. The bottom type can be wired up, then inserted into part. TEST!!, then push back in and sew to vest.

GUN:
Disassemble gun, desolder the touch pad from the wires when the connector goes in. Insert the new socket into the new 3D part (push IN, then DOWN, then insert the wires through the hole provided). Solder to gun wires and place the part into one side of the gun (There is no push button, it needs to be done prior to reassembly. Part reassemble and check. Finish assembly, including hand grip covers.

I recommend all connectors be soldered using heat shrink covers, in the case of the vest I used 2 layers, one per wire, and one larger tube to cover all.

If you have any questions shoot... no pun intended :)

author: Painless360

description.text: Wanted to hang the charger in a closet with enough airflow behind for cooling.

Tuned bell siphon based on https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2119390 (parametric OpenScad). Design is targetting a growbed about 11-13 cm deep and works fine without the bottom cup (see further tuning below). We used 20mm diametrer and 9cm height. Tickness of 1mm for reducing printing time (looks rigid enough).

Model is upside down ready to print.

Post-print tuning: the design will probably not work directly because snorkel is quite long and will not allow the siphon to stop without the cup accessory (depending on pump flow and exit diameter). To fix this, you can just try to cut small bits off the snorkel until you can reach the point where the air will flow in to stop the siphon.

in our case:

  • snorkel cut at 3cm from bottom (so min water = 3cm)
  • max water = 7.5cm, leaving about 4cm dry on top
  • exit diameter=8mm
  • growbed of about 10l
  • tide time about 4:15 min (2:30 up and 1:45 down)
  • pump: low debit (air powered actually using our venturi design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2818751)

youtube video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M_YMewBTQvI

author: jprofesorek

description.text:
WIRELESS MAILBOX NOTIFIER

This electronic mailbox notifier gives by means of a transceiver, over a distance of a few hundreds of meters, a message that the mail has delivered.
As soon as the lid of the mailbox opens, the transmitter will send for a half second a signal to the receiver in the house. The receiver will produce then an intermitting signal (beep sound or led flash) until reset.
Building the electronic mailbox notifier is not difficult, but it needs some knowledge of electronics.
In our case the signal has to send to the house over a distance of 150m through the forest.

Switch in mailbox

The switch consist of a reed contact which will be activated by a magnet when the lid or the door in the mail box will be opened.
A reed contact is weather proof and it is operated by a magnet. Moreover it has a very long life time and the contact is reliable.
The construction of the reed switch is shown in the added drawings.

The dipolantenna (self-made)

Material:

  • 36cm electricity tube 5/8".
  • 2 x insulated copper electricity wire
    2,5mm2, length each 17,3cm.

The dipolantenna can easy be made from two insulated electricity wires, each 17.5 cm. To prevent oxidation it is recommended to keep the insulation on the wire. The wave length lambda (in m) can be easily calculated by dividing 300 by the used frequency (in MHz). The result is shown in m. In this case the frequency is 433 MHz, so the wave length is 300:433= 0.69m. A dipol antenna is usally based on 1/4 lambda, so both dipol parts have each a length of 0.69 : 4 = 0,173 (17,3 cm). By placing the wires into a standard 5/8" electricity tube a solid unit will be obtained.

description.text:
Award winning toilet paper holder. "2nd prize design contest ReprapWorld March 2018".

I just needed a fancy toilet paper holder. It escalated a bit. The final printed monstrosity weighs in at a hefty 3.5KG.

Each of the hexagon cups was printed in about 16 hours.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

dynamic

Infill:

dynamic

Notes:

Use dynamic resolution so that the strait parts are printed in 0.25mm layer height and the overhangs at 0.15mm layer height. If your slicer cant slice with dynamic layer heights, use 0.15mm on whole object.

Use dynamic infill. Default to 10mm infill. Use the infill mesh stl to dynamically change the infill to 3mm for supporting the skin better. If you cannot use dynamic infill, experiment first with a 33% scaled version and test how the skin printing behaves at like 5mm infill.

Print 2 pieces of the stl with the mouting hole. Print as many pieces you like of the stl without the mounting hole.

Assembly

Arrange all the printed pieces in a nice pattern of your liking. Put the ones with the mounting holes on the outside of the shape.

When happy, glue all pieces together. For me Bison Poly Max ® Crystal Express worked out great to glue PLA.

MMMMM Cupcakes! Ever wonder how the one armed man eats cupcakes? Now's your chance to find out, see my design for a prosthetic 'hand'. With a Cupcake CNC printer you can make your own prosthetic hand to practice eating cupcakes, dress up for Halloween, scare your mother or as I had envisioned provide prostheses to areas affective by war, disease, natural disasters or the like. Using a Cupcake CNC printer and a basic hand and wrist design will allow for inexpensive production in areas with little resources. The fact that the printer is portable and affordable allows for someone like myself (a prosthetic technician) to travel to places like Haiti and make be low elbow prothesis on the spot for victims. The opportunities to assist people with low cost prosthesis are endless with the Cupcake CNC printer!!!
And if you don't know an amputee or don't want to scare your mother this design can be used as an in home grabber for hard to reach shelves (I just make my gorgeous tall wife do it for me) or as claws for your robot army as they take over the world. As you can see something for the bleeding hearts and the hearts taking over the world, something for everyone!

The Prosthetic Hand Kit beefs up existing prosthetic hand designs to make them durable when printed in plastic. This kit provides designs for left or right straight hook prosthetic, wrist unit and laminating fabrication cap. This kit can be used to make a fully functional below elbow prosthesis to be used with a few items from a local hardware store.
The 4 parts to be printed are: hand, thumb, wrist unit, and fabrication cap. Each printed part is separated into individual files for printing. Print each part and assemble with one 1/4 inch wide nut and bolt, two 1/8 inch wide nut and bolt, parachute cord or the like, webbing and rubber bands of any size . The wrist is designed to be used with a vacuum form plastic socket (not printable) which the fabrication cap is needed for. Once you have the socket and hand assembled you can use the shoulder harnessing of your choice and use your prosthetic.

Items needed:

Tools needed:

-Soldering Iron

-Handbrake board code (this code enables the board to push the COMMA keyboard button mapped to our switch).

You can also do do it like in this video guide:

author: Bikecyclist

title: Interchangeable Shower Soap Dish System
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Fits a 25mm shower riser tube.
Shower riser tube to wall clearance needs to be at least 25mm. 30mm recommended.

The original shower soap holder was just a flat piece of plastic with a recess on either side for a bar of soap.
After a few showers, the soap would block the drain holes and it would all turn it into a tray with two puddles of goo in it.

I made my own tray where you can remove the dishes for easy cleaning. The colours of the trays were picked to match that of the soap - so the soap-dishes look cleaner for longer.

The blades in the dishes allow air to get underneath a wet bar of soap and allow then to dry out after each use.

The tray is tilted down at the front to encourage water to drip away from the wall.

There are large rounded drip edges on dishes to allow water to drain out from all but the most caked-up dish.
The drip edges also serve as a locator that stops them accidentally being knocked out of the tray.
They are rounded to reduce the chance of injury.
A compromise was that the bottom of the dishes are flat to allow easy printing without support that a hanging drip-edge would require, but the tray angle compensates for this.
Support is needed however for the overhanging locating brim, but any mess this support causes is hidden in the recess.

The tray was printed in rigid.ink Black ASA.
ASA was used as the sun shines into my bathroom and there was a good chance the sun would bleach black non-UV-safe plastics.
The dishes were printed in rigid.ink ABS (Colours: Olive Green, White, Pink) as they can easily be replaced if they fade.

Another reason for using ASA and ABS was so that the parts could be easily acetone-vapour smoothed.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.12mm tray, 0.14mm dishes

Infill:

70% tray, 50% dishes

Notes:

The ASA tray print settings are -
Layers: 0.12mm, 8 top, 4 bottom, 3 shells
Infill: 70% Full Honeycomb
Support: None
Print Temperature: 230°C
Bed Temperature: 90°C
Cooling: None
Speed: 35mm/s

ABS dishes -
Layers: 0.14mm, 6 top, 4 bottom, 2 shells
Infill: 50% Full Honeycomb
Support: Yes. 35%, extra inflation 0.6mm, resolution 1mm, 45°, 2 dense layers at 90%
Print Temperature: 235°C
Bed Temperature: 90°C
Cooling: None
Speed: 45mm/s

Remove support off the dishes, and general cleanup of all parts.

Optional step -
Acetone-smoothing: I acetone-smoothed/polished to improve water-tightness/resistance and improve the general appearance.

The method I used is documented here - https://rigid.ink/blogs/news/acetone-vapor-smoothing

This a little 3 inch plus frame racing quad I designed. Its really more of a novelty than anything else. It's pretty fun to fly, and gets peoples attention when you pull it out. I fly this on the 20mm HGLRC stack, with 1407 3600kv motors and a runcam swift micro.

The pod is designed to have M3 nuts embedded into the print. After slicing the STL look to see the nut wells in the print. Pause the print just before the layer that covers the nut and install nuts, and resume printing. This seems to work pretty well for me and I haven't had any issues mounting the pod this way.

I included the STEP file for the base plate. If you have access to be able to cut your own, go for it. If not, and it's something that interests you, send me a message and I will cut one for you.

Blue Skies!

Mark McBride
Carbonite RC

description.text: Was looking for a cup holder for my Peugeot 306 Break 2001 but haven't found any that fits my needs so I designed this one in Fusion360. The holes on the actual "cup" of the print are there just to reduce time and plastic used on this print because without any holes it would be just under 100gr. I made another one with more holes but sadly I'm almost out of filament so I did print it. If you don't want to make holes in your car interior like I did I guess you could use hot glue or something like that because the hinge part is a very tight fit to the car.

An upgraded power coupler for the Shopsmith, as I wasnt happy with the other designs on this site. Mine features:

  • Ring on outside shows the side with 4 internal splines (for me this is the drive side)
  • External grooves matching location of these splines so you can see where to line up
  • Chamfered entrances to help slot in the drive hubs (still a snug fit once in)
  • Designed for 3d printing! No horizontal overhangs.
  • Straight tube on the outside, i.e. no thinner section in the middle. From a stress point of view, it's better to keep the maximum outer diameter and take material off the inside.

I printed mine in ABS with Slic3r settings: 30% infill using 3d honeycomb, 4 vertical shells minimum. Just spun her up and seems to fit and work just fine. But I cannot gaurentee this will work for you, I am not using a high force application (strip sander attachment), so if in doubt use more infill!

Note: The external grooves to show location of splines were actually an afterthough I added after I printed my own, if you print this and think they are too small and not visible enough then let me know and I'll make them a bit deeper.

title: Flir Exx Exxbx Tripod Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a Tripod Mount for the Flir Exx(bx) camera series.
There have been complaints that the original tripod adapter accessory was both very expensive ($50) and yet not very stable.
Therefore created a cheap and stable version that anyone can 3D print, that fit multiple tripods, including the very common Manfrotto 200PL-14 mount plate.

The adapter has a thumbscrew wheel to secure it to the thermal imager, as well as a Velcro-strap to further stabilize it to the handle of the imager.
It uses 2pcs 3/8 -> 1/4 UNC adapters to be able to provide a metal thread for the tripods screw.
The Thumbwheel has to be threaded with a M5 thread.

[REQUIRED HARDWARE]
1 pcs M5x14 hex socket screw (insex)
2 pcs 3/8 -> 1/4 UNC adapter
1 pcs Velcro-strap (20 mm wide, ~155mm loops, ~80mm hooks)

Optionally, can place 1mm soft one-sided foam tape at the top surface and handle surface to further minimize risk of wear.

Introducing Pocket-Dungeons! A modular, competitive dungeon-crawl for two to six players. With modular, tile-based board design and randomized events, no two games will be alike. Dynamic, tactical game play allows for quick resolution as players control treasure-hungry dungeon delvers vying for gold and glory. This game has been designed with Pocket-Tactics in mind and the pieces and rules sets will be able to cross over and expand the depth of each range. For the Pocket-Tactics stuff, head on over here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27257 Also, check out our blog for updates on our projects, contests and the like: http://illgottengames.blogspot.com/ All models designed in the amazing Tinkercad: https://tinkercad.com/users/bHIdLANxoGl

Models printed with a 10% infill at a .10 layer height. Each set should include:
-6 delvers (Warrior, Wizard, Elf, Dwarf, Thief, and Priestess.)
-10 dwellers (2 Skittering Fiends, 2 Restless Spirits, 2 Hogboglins, 2 Shambling Corpses, 1 Cave Gronk, and 1 Ancient Guardian)
-40 dungeon tiles (print the tile set twice)
-6 door markers
-13 counters (6 Treasure counters, 6 Hazard counters, and 1 Stairs counter)
-12 six-sided dice (6 red Offense dice and 6 blue Defense dice) (These weren't printed, though I suppose you could)
I painted everything in standard, hardware store spraypaint. Still playing around with coloration....
The rules are hyper-fresh, so expect lots of revisions. Enjoy!

description.text: Desktop Caliper Micrometer stand

This is a remix from the 1/200 scale Bergman treasure chest.

I up-scaled it to 28mm (1/56th) scale. I separated the tracks, adding the tread lug pattern, and created new main gun (as a separate file) and new turret MGs. I also created a "pivot" for the turret mount, as I find this stronger in 3d printing then turrets with the pivot as one part.

In Bolt Action, this actually isn't a bad tank - two turret MMGs and a light ATG in the hull, with armour of 8+ (light tank). I was used by the Italians in North Africa as well post-capture by the Australians (please see photo). It was even used in the Italian campaign in small numbers

http://www.tanks-encyclopedia.com/ww2/italy/Carro_Armato_Medio_M11-39.php

again, my apologies for the lack of photo clarity with the black filament. I haven't had a chance to paint many of my prints yet!

description.text:
To promote the #MRRF2018 and the #OpenRC #F1 World Championships https://www.matterhackers.com/open-rc-contest I felt like contributing with new deep groove tires (for the original OpenRC F1 car rims) that hopefully will flex nicely and give good grip on the race track (if not they at least look pretty nice if I may say so myself). If you would rather use my low profile tires I recommend these versions: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1274262 https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1272295

Perhaps it´s also a good idea to make your car a bit more crash-safe prior to racing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1884110 https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1968442

And if you believe a diff will help you when using the low-profile tires, these rims will help: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2716222 (the differential designed by Tor Arne Hustvedt can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2361718)

These tires are designed for printing with 0,4 or 0,7mm nozzles.

Emanuel from http://te3d.se/ https://www.instagram.com/te3d.se/ has helped me in this project to validate print-ability, he used my 85 shore A ETPU 85-700+ Carbon Black and a 0,7mm nozzle. The pics/prints shown here are from him, thanks Emanuel!

Enjoy and good luck in i the race!

The base cutter will cut bottom (or top) to size.

description.text: I've taken the Three-D Dragon Curve "Dragon_10" model by pmoews into MeshMixer and made it into a large, organic-looking fractal pendant or amulet. I made it solid, gave it some "pylons" and webbed-finger bits to strengthen the weak links between iterations, and gave it some extra bulk, making it look more organic and messy. I also put a ~5mm diameter tunnel in an end to thread a necklace chain through. Will update with pics modeling the amulet when the chain gets delivered.

author: nowa_k

description.text:
This is a design for a "Stream Cheap", an inexpensive DIY version of the Elgato Stream Deck. Although I made this to take the place of a Stream Deck, it's really a mini macro keyboard that can be used as a hotkey board for any program.

More info is available on my website.

All design files are licensed as Creative Commons - Attribution - Share-Alike. The firmware for the Arduino is licensed under the more permissive MIT license.

1. Print out both parts and tap the bolt holes in the base to fit an M3 bolt.
  2. Insert the switches into the faceplate and wire them up. One post of each switch needs a signal wire, and all of the other posts are connected to ground.
  3. Solder everything to the Arduino. The ground connection goes to "GND" and the signal wires to go pins 2 - 9. I numbered my buttons from left to right and top to bottom, but you can wire them in any order that you like. If you have the connectors, use those rather than making direct connections.
  4. Bolt on the faceplate to the body.
  5. Print out the button icons and apply them to the keycaps. Firmly press the keycaps onto the button stems.
  6. Upload the firmware and enjoy!

Required:
  • 5V Arduino Pro Micro
  • 8 Cherry MX Switches
  • 8 Relegendable Keycaps
  • 2 M3-10 Bolts

You will also need a USB cable, solder, and a piece of double-sided tape.

Optional:
  • 9 Pin Female Connector
  • 9 Pin Male Connector, Right-Angle

remixed_from.author: Despair
remixed_from.title: 1610 CNC end stop switches mounts and parts

description.text:
I managed to strip the bolt for tightening the spindle on my Linksprite 1610 CNC. I decided to take the time to model up an entire replacement carriage (with help from a few measurements).

Features:

  1. the carriage is entirely parametric.

  2. It features a lifted spindle clamp to increase clamping surface when using an ER11 collet, which tends to be longer than the stock collet.

  3. it uses a GoPro knob for clamping the spindle (25mm M5 bolt and M5 nut).

  4. (optional) The wide body version basically has Despair's Z endstop plate built in on either side, plus a cable tie mount point.

  5. (optional) built-in dovetail mounts on either side of the spindle for accessories like dust collection and camera mounts. Still designing those bits.

There's two versions; a wide-body version with a lifted clamping section, dovetail mounts, and endstop mounts (which I'm using) and something close to stock with just the improved front clamp.

I've included a trivial block for removing the LM8UU bearings without damage (they're not in too tight). The screw nut is a bit tighter, but still pops out easily enough.

Supports:

No

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printed in Hatchbox PETG

title: Titan Extruder Mount for DreamMaker OverLord

description.text:
This is a mount for the E3D Titan extruder for DreamMaker OverLord/Pro 3D printer.

Print the mount and cut the plastic body of the printer accordingly to the size of the mount. I used a soldering iron with flat tip.

You need to use a shorter stepper motor for this mount since the original motor won't fit in that area of the printer. Currently I'm using E3D Slimline Stepper Motor with clone TMC2100 driver at 1A (max) and with this setup, sometimes the motor would stall at faster retraction speed. Filament loading/unloading from the printer's Menu would stall the motor as well (because of the high speed). My solution at the moment is just slowing down the retraction speed and manually insert/remove the filament by hand.

From this experience, I would recommend to use a stepper motor with higher torque than the one that I have since I didn't experience this issue with the original motor from the printer. Probably best to use something like E3D Compact But Powerful Motor.

I would also recommend to get the Tevo Titan extruder instead as I think the mechanism works better - the lever doesn't put any stresses to the motor's shaft, as opposed to the original extruder from E3D.

YMMV.

remixed_from.author: 85holmberg
remixed_from.title: Anet A8, easy removable extruder cooling fan

title: Removable Extruder Fan Holder A8
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This design allows you to easily replace your filament by manually removing the extruder fan.
The extruder fan sits on on sliding slot, and to remove it you just need to pull it up.

This is a remix from 85holmberg's design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2326111
In his design you had to use other screw size and need to cut the extruder heatsink. I did not want to cut the heatsink as I might need it in the future, so I redesigned his concept.

In this design, I removed the heatsink and put the fan at 15 degrees, blowing directly to the extruder parts.
As the moving air might reach the nozzle and cooling it, I designed an exhaust below the fan so that the air moves through there not affecting the nozzle temp.

Some may say removing the heatsink is a bad move, but it is working for me!
Temps are okay, and prints were not affected.
This piece weights almost nothing, so it will not affect any carriage movement.

What you need to know:

  • print the design
  • remove the heatsink and fan cover
  • use the same two 50mm screws to put the mount in place
  • simply slide the fan in!

title: Prusa i3 Mk2s MMU Modified Extruder For Bowden Style Input
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I didn't like the feed input to the extruder, and if you have the spools above the printer, the filament can rub the extruder, and in my case make a squeaking noise that was annoying.

But this is also part of a frame support for 4 filament rolls, and i was using the 4mm OD PTFE tube. but i felt that some people might want just the extruder to fit in with their setup

Parts List:
2 modified Extruders
4 M5 x 7mm Brass inserts
4 Festo QSM-M5-4 Push-in Fittings
4mm OD 2mm ID PTFE Tube (Cut to Length)

I used M5 x 7mm brass inserts that i found on Ebay. loads available for not allot of money. i tried to match what Prusa used, by they worked out very expensive in comparison.

I used Festo QSM-M5-4 Push Fittings i purchased from RS Online. These are the same as the ones Prusa inlcuded with the MMU

https://uk.rs-online.com/web/p/pneumatic-straight-threaded-to-tube-adaptors/1216037/

i reused the brass insert from the Prusa extruder. i screwed in a Push fitting (a screw or bolt will do, i just didn't have any M5 fixings here) and with a bit of force and a pair of pliers, you can wiggle and pull the existing brass inserts out. also take the short PTFE tube as well.

all brass fittings are press fit, or if you want you can heat up the plastic before pushing in. i used a vice. don't Forget to fit the short PTFE tube.

i have made the hole 7.1mm, this is do to material expanding and making the hole smaller

4 Roll frame holder https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2822310

When cutting PTFE DO NOT use side cutters, it crushes the tube before cutting and makes it oval, which makes it harder for the filament to push through. Use a sharp craft knife and it stays round.

description.text:
While I've built numerous boats that use 3d-printed 2212 Brushless Nacelles, The boats themselves are always quite ugly and build from soda bottles. Therefore, I've been playing for a while in Freecad to build a decent RC boat hull. This is the Result!

In order to make this function, you will need the following:

  • 2x 2212 Brushless Motors
  • 2x 3mm to 6mm Prop adapter.
  • 2x 30A Brushless ESC's
  • 1x 3S LiPo Battery
  • 1x Standard RC Servo
  • 1x RC Radio System

For Hadware (Recommend all Stainless Steel!!!) :

  • 1x M4x60 - Rudder
  • 4x M3x10 - Rudder and Servo Mounting Plate
  • 4x M3x8 - Servo Mount
  • 8x M3x6 - Motor Mount

To assemble, print out all the hull pieces and stick them together with ABS slurry. I recommend starting with the Hull, and making sure it's all smooth and nicely joined before attaching the motor nacelle.

I have attached cut-up .stl's of the hull that will fit in a 250mmx150mmx150mm print area. If this doesn't work for your printer, the full hull is available for your own cutting.

After installing the motors and verifying their functionality, Fill the cable holes in with Hot Glue or Epoxy.

The Rudder/Servo mount attach with screws. I still have not tested if this is a good seal or not. If it is not, I will be designing a NinjaFlex Gasket.

Still to do:

  • Hatch to close up the hull
  • Decorative Cabin with FPV Gimbal and stabilizer
  • Motor Controller and Battery Mounts
  • Water Cooling Fixtures for Motor Controllers
  • Design propellers

title: Lockout for CANVAS Evelyn Display Cabinet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This lockout device is designed to enable the use of small lock to keep little fingers away from collectibles stored in a display cabinet.

Compatible with CANVAS Evelyn Cabinet Product #068-7560-4 and Master Lock Model No. 646D. Note that the lock shackle diameter is 3.2mm and that the spacing between the cabinet door knobs varies depending on the door adjustments. This lockout device easily accommodates spacing between 15.8mm and 20.8mm (measured at the widest part of the knobs). The lockout device is designed specifically to work with the knobs present on the CANVAS Evelyn Cabinet.

Printer:

Flashforge Inventor

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.08mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Both parts are printed at the same time. I recommend the use of an 8mm skirt/brim at the base and between 4 and 6 perimeters/shells.

This was one of my most difficult projects. It took me nine iterations until I achieved a decent fit and strength. I had initially only measured the dimensions of one pair of cabinet knobs and had not realized that each pair required a different fit. Once this was corrected, I realized that the lockout device was too weak and the lock hole broke easily. Once this was corrected, I realized that the device could be removed without knowing the lock combination simply by wiggling the device and pulling on the doors. I went through more iterations to get the parts to print properly without seizing.

title: Pergo Cope and Drag Alignment for Sand Casting

description.text:
When using green sand for casting aluminium your cope and drag boxes need to be aligned correctly. Put a set of these on the end of the long sides of your boxes and screw them to the box. Then when placing the boxes together for the pour, they will be perfectly aligned.

I personally printed them on their ends (as pictured), and used NO supports. This is the true reason for the filet on the parts. Gives a gradual width increase as you move up the model.
I printed in PLA

I included the Solidworks 2016 source files in case you want to change for smaller jewelry boxes, or MUCH larger for say engine blocks :P
