Yet another FanDuct for Titan Aero. Uses the fan holder by GaryK47 and standard 50mm blower.

I tried bunch of duct's available and they all blow air all around and are not focusing air properly, I tried modifying some of them but finally gave up and made one from scratch, it's as ugly as they come but works surprisingly well. It requires heater block to be in line with the aluminum heat sink of the Aero. If you screw on your heater block and it's at the angle, loosen your nozzle a bit, turn heat block to be parallel to the alu heat sink (so wires go towards motor or towards heat sink fan, not to the side) and then tighten your nozzle.

  • print
  • push the fan duct into your blower
  • attach blower to the fan holder
  • print happy

prints easily without support both in PETG and ABS. I doubt PLA would work well for fan duct so I never tried it myself but if you do please update comments on how well it performs printed in PLA :D I personally doubt PLA will work ok as the fan duct surrounds the heat block so I fear PLA would get soft and bend.

V2 allows for easier cable management and is little lighter

source available as always on onshape

p.s. the white grid on top of the replaced fan (this is sunone maglev that's super quiet with high air troughput) is thing:2335067 printed in TPU, between fan and heat sink is same thing scaled in Z also printed in TPU, it should make the flow from fan more laminar but is in reality printed 'cause I don't have screws of right size so for using longer screws I added this 7mm "distancer" ... also the white pieces on the part blower fan are also just a fat TPU washers I printed as screws are too long :)

middle hole

if your heater block is oriented as one on my pictures, melt a piece of filament (or use a piece of tape or..) and close the small hole in the middle between the arms as in this orientation that hole does not do anything useful (and might even do harm), the middle hole should remain open if your heater block is 180 degrees from what my pictures show

title: ShakeBot Racers - Explore the Engineering Process

description.text:
YouTube Video https://youtu.be/R-_KxKbB8wU

This is a fun exploration of the engineering process as well as some core physics concepts including:
Newton's Second Law
Transfer of Energy
Friction

Using the ShakeIt Mini from Lectrify http://www.lectrify.it/products/shake-it-mini-bulk-pack as a platform, students design legs for their racer to see how fast they can make it go. This encourages iteration and testing.

This particular demo uses flexible filament from Recreus
NGSS

This is a project to explore the engineering process through iteration and testing. It also exposes students to core concepts such as transfer of energy, centripetal force, relationship of mass and energy (Newton's 2nd Law) and friction.

Why does it vibrate?

The core of the project is a vibrating motor on the Lectrify Shake It or Shake It Mini boards. The vibrating motor works by spinning an unbalanced mass which causes vibrations from the centripetal force on that unbalanced mass.

Design Challenge

Once the students have observed the board move with the provided legs, they are encouraged to design their own legs. Specific challenges can be:

  • Design the fastest shakebot
  • Design the most precise (go in a straight line)
  • Design the funniest shakebot
Materials - Friction and transfer of energy.

As students design their legs, they are encouraged to explore different materials.

How well do rigid materials like PLA and ABS work as legs?

How does the leg design influence the function of the robot?

Why does flexible filament work different from ABS or PLA?

How can you modify friction after printing? (sandpaper, glues, tape...)

Mass and Energy - Newton's 2nd Law

Newton's second law says F=ma
In this system, the force is constant because it is created by the motor and battery. Therefore, students can explore what happens to acceleration when they change the mass. How does a heavier bot move compared to a lighter one?

Materials Needed

This project works best if you can print with a variety of materials including ABS, PLA and flexible filament.

The project is also designed to work with the ShakeIt Mini from Lectrify. They can be purchased in bulk here: http://www.lectrify.it/products/shake-it-mini-bulk-pack

It is also recommended to use glue dots to fasten the legs to the ShakeIt Minis.

author: krummrey

description.text: This is a device for people who can not lift their arm higher than table level. It can be operated with arms below table or even with a foot (need to adapt the handle for that). This is the basic structure; you will need to add attachments to make it functional. It clamps to a table top surface. As one moves the bottom handle back and forth or up and down, the top lever does the same thing. If you attach a sandwich holder or a fork to the top lever this device can allow individuals some independence in feeding themselves without using trunk flexion. For children with limitations in reach, one could attach a puppet holder or clip to hold a doll or stuffed animal (light) to allow play in vertical planes. One could also attach a paintbrush or bingo marker to make art projects.

This costs about 10$ in supplies from home center store plus 3D printed parts and attachments.

Need:
½ inch PVC pipe
• 16” piece for vertical bar, about 12” piece for top bar, and about 8” piece for handle
1 inch PVC pipe
• About 10” for vertical bar mechanism
½ inch collar fitting (which you will cut down)
1 aluminum bar ½” x 1/16” x 36 inches. Cut down to 16”.
4 binding pins: 3/16x 1”
3D printed forked posts- 2
3D printed paddle with pipe clamp if needed/or glue
Accessories to attach to top bar depending on usage
Glue for PVC pipe, clamp

Directions

  1. Use band saw or hack saw to cut neck off pipe fitting. Cut enough off to allow it to fit down a length of the ½” pipe. This will make the collar on the vertical bar.

  2. Using Pipe Cutters or a Hack Saw, Cut PVC pipes to desired lengths. The two horizontal bars are a matter of usage and personal preference . You can change them as desired and it will not effect the mechanism within reason. The length of the vertical bar needs to be a little more exact- if its varied- the length of the aluminum bar should be made roughly the same length.

  3. Draw a line centered down the 16” pipe. Drill a 5/16” hole straight through pipe 2.5 inches from each end. Use the line to make sure the holes are aligned in the pipe evenly.
    Use a band saw to cut two lines up to the drilled hole on each side, creating a slit like this.

  4. Cut the aluminum bar to the same length as your vertical ½” PVC pipe, 16”.

  5. Drill ¼” holes in the vertical ½ PVC pipe on the remaining smooth sides (90 degrees away from the last holes) about 1.5” away from the ends. There should be one set of holes on each end of the pipe and they should be aligned with one another.

  6. Drill ¼” holes in the aluminum bar exactly the same distance apart as on the pipe.

  7. Get your 3D printed forked posts (2) and drill a ¼”hole through each, ½” away from the forked end. This will allow you to attach the aluminum bar in the slit using a binding pin.

  8. Drill another ¼” hole in each of the 3D printed bars, 3” from end (forked). This hole will allow a binding pin to attach it to you vertical support. This should be through the solid part of the bar (thinner).
    Now you are ready to assemble. You will need glue (one that will work with PVC).

  9. Glue the blunt side of one of the 3D printed forks into the 12” long piece of ½” PVC. This will be the top part of the mechanism.

  10. Glue the blunt side of the other 3D printed forks into the 8” long piece of ½” PVC. This will be the handle.

  11. Take the 16” piece of ½” PVC and fit the collar around one end. Until it is very snug about 3.5” down from the end of the pipe. This can be glued when you are certain about placement.

  12. Fit the 3D printed paddle onto the 1” PVC pipe about 3” from bottom end. Secure with glue or clamp

  13. Now slide the 16” long ½” PVC into the 10” long 1” PVC pipe. The larger pipe should be blocked from movement when it hit the collar.

  14. Fasten binding pins. (2) One through each end of the forked 3D printed post with the aluminum bar.
  15. Fasten binding pins (2). One holding the 3D printed posted inside the slit cut at each end of the 16” vertical PVC.
    Now you have the basic mechanism. You can add a foam pad (pipe insulation) to the handle. Add a elbow joint or other joint to the top bar depending on what you would like to use it for.

I made this to help me with draining my friends carburators(straight 4 line engine). It makes it possible to drain all four at the same time with no hassle. This is the second thing I made in 3D. Note:
ABS plastics WILL disolve when in contact with gasoline.
This was printed in both ABS and Ultem.
I left both in a bath of gasoline over night and the ABS part got disolved. This does not really matter since the gasoline is drained and won't be used again, just remember to clean it after use. For those of you that want to, you can try to cover it in 2K Clear, this should eliminate leakage(not really a problem if hung correctly, the gasoline will drain before it leaks) and it should keep the model from dissolving. 2K Clear can be bought pretty much everywhere in a can. Once the seal is broken the can must be used and I would recommend to use it all on this model to get a nice layer of clear, I would imagine the first 2 or three layers will get into the pours of the model so just keep on spraying acording to the instructions for your 2K Clear provider. The ULTEM model worked like a charm. This project was made possible by www.protech.se

title: Prusa i3 Mk2s MMU Frame Spool Support (4 Spools) Space Saver
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Space is a premium for me, so i wanted to create a 4 spool holder that attached to the top of the frame, and also gave a easier way to feed the filament in to the extruder, than trying to feed in into the bottom of the extruder.

I have been testing this for the last couple of months, and with some tweaks (what the files are now) i have something i am happy with. printing at speeds of upto 70mm/s get no noticeable vibrations/rocking, and print quality has been unaffected. I am aware that some clone printer with a plastic frame can experience the frame bending with weight added to it, which affects the print quality. But with the Original Prusa i3 MK2s frame being metal, i haven't noticed it.

i normally print PETG at 20-40mm/s and its rock solid.

inbetween the supports and you can upto 100mm wide spools on the rollers, but if you stagger over the supports you could get wider. but most spools i have, seem to be less than 100mm wide.

the bend in the PTFE tube is higher than the highest point the nozzle can go, so it wont interfere with tall prints.

Parts List:
2 Prusa i3 Mk2s MMU Modified Extruder For Bowden Style Input
3 Spool Frame Supports
4 Filament Guides
16 Bearing housings
4 end Caps
4 250mm long 4mm OD 2mm id PTFE tube
4 M5 x 7mm brass inserts
4 Festo QSM-M5-4 Push-in Fittings
16 Bearings from the Prusa MMU Filament Rollers
2 500mm long 8mm OD 6mm id Carbon Fibre rods
3 160 x 2.6mm Zip Ties (same ones supplied by Prusa)

I used M5 x 7mm brass inserts that i found on Ebay. loads available for not allot of money. i tried to match what Prusa used, by they worked out very expensive in comparison.

I used Festo QSM-M5-4 Push Fittings i purchased from RS Online. These are the same as the ones Prusa inlcuded with the MMU

https://uk.rs-online.com/web/p/pneumatic-straight-threaded-to-tube-adaptors/1216037/

Slightly modified Bearing housing/Wheel, i modified the design from this design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1832235. My design has slightly higher sides.

I modified the Prusa Extruder to take a 4mm OD PTFE Tube from the Filament Guide.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2822229

The Bearings are from the MMU Spool holders. saves having to buy some.

the Rods are 500mm long 8mm OD 6mm ID Carbon Fibre rods. i bought these because Carbon Fibre is cool. the inside Diameter of the Bearings are 8mm, and because of that are too tight for the 8mm rod. i sanded to rod to be slightly thinner, and to allow the bearings to slide along the length with out friction.

the Holes for the brass insers are 7.2mm diameter, to allow for material expansion, making the hole smaller. i press fit these in cold, but you could use a little heat if you wanted, to make the plastic plyable.

the fillament guides are designed to have a little bit of flex, to allow them to snap over the rods. they can also slide freely, so they can be position where best for the filament roll you have

The Supports have a internal channel to allow the zip ties to tie round the frame. this is a must, as the weight of the filament and the over hang pull the support over. the zip tie is fed in from the back, it comes out the bottom of the front leg, is wrapped around the frame, and goes into the bottom of the rear leg. through the locking part of the zip tie and it comes out of the top of the support, if you pull it tight with pliers, then wrap it round the pliers jaw and twist (as shown in the photos) you will get a couple extra "clicks" and the zip tie will be very tight. this is important to stop any vibrations/rocking/failing of the support.

the end caps are to stop the end bearings falling off, and to highlight the ends of the rods to make them more visible.

When cutting PTFE DO NOT use side cutters, it crushes the tube before cutting and makes it oval, which makes it harder for the filament to push through. Use a sharp craft knife and it stays round.

The Light that is in the photo is this one https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2791701

description.text:
The Fully Printable 3x3 Puzzle by constrain3d is pretty great. I just printed it, but it needed a splash of color. With this tile plate you can add color while still keeping the puzzle fully printable!

Print six copies of the tile plate in different colors, and glue them to the assembled puzzle. Traditionally the color scheme is blue opposite green, red opposite orange, and yellow opposite white. One corner is blue, yellow, and red, clockwise in that order. But pick any colors you like!

It should be a quick print! The raft takes longer than the tiles themselves, haha. If you'd like thicker tiles, scale the Z axis.

author: AndrewSink

title: Creality CR-10s / CR-10 - Filament Sensor Upgrade - Base Version

description.text:
Dear Makers,

I think we all know the 'good' Filament Sensor, that comes with the Creality CR-10s.
I had so much problems with that flimsy black box that Creality delivered, that I decided to completely re-design the Box of the Filament Sensor.
The good thing is, you re-use the original PCB, Screws and Tubing.
I actually build 8 Versions before I was absolutely satisfied. No-More problems getting the Filament through, no more problems that the Filament experiences friction, the box is fixated and Filament-replacements are now just fun.

I include a small Foto- Manual, although, I do not think any of you would need it.
(Please ignore the second-part of the manual, where the 'MegaWheel' -version is described)

There is also a 'MegaWheel' Version of this sensor available, for all you guys who likes to have the Filament-Spool on top of the CR-10(s) - Printer. The 'MegaWheel' -version, reduces friction to a minimum and guides the Filament 'so-nicely' ;) .

If you tested it out and are happy, give me a thumbs-up.

Happy printing,

Johnflimsey

title: Simple spool holder with bearings

description.text:
This is a remix of my own original simple spool holder ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2704291 ), I wanted to see if I could keep the same shape/function while adding ball bearings to it and to be able to print everything as flat as possible. So here it is :)

It will hold spools down to a 42mm inside hole.
It uses a locking key to keep the spool on it with different positions to accommodate different spool width. The frame also have a couple holes to store the key during spool change.

-1x 5/16th-18 x5" bolt
-2x 608zz Ball bearings
-10x #4x3/4 flat head metal screws for Feet
-2x #4x1/2 flat head metal screws for roller (3/8 lenghts works too)

If there is enough interest I may modify it to use some Metric hardware.

This is a luxury entrance for bee hives. Its intended to go on the super as entrances in the super are meant to increase honey yields by making it easier for the returning bees to access the supers. Not sure if this is the case or not so is a bit of an experiment. I will find out this spring and if the bees actually use it!

The entrance has a roof over the entrance to prevent rain ingress and a landing pad to assist the bees, but angled to allow water to drain away from the hive.

The doors can be opened and allow you to adjust the entrance hole size. They can be closed in case of robbing.

The pointed base is intended to direct the bees to the ledge if they are climbing up the hive.

Can be unclipped from the hive and blanking plate placed over the super hole when transporting if required.

This is printed in fluorescent yellow but only because that was the colour I had loaded at the time and not for any bee specific reason.

Dimension of landing pad is max 60mm wide, with approximate 40mm wide x 8mm high entrance slot.

It's fitted to my poly hive super in the photo.

Print two doors, and fit them in the slot before you attach the entrance to the hive.

Would be interested to hear beekeeping comments on it.

title: MULTIPLE Strap buckle for loop at end of leash

description.text:
I created these female buckles to help people that may need to tie several buckles to one single strap or leash. It is sort of a remix of my original "Strap buckle for loop at end of leash".
The leash width is 1inch.
You'll need 1.8-1.9" long by 1/4" bolt (and nut) to fix the buckle to the loop on your leash. The bolt should have a good part of a smooth surface (no thread). The less thread that is in contact with the leash the better in terms of future wear.
I keyed the female buckle to match my male buckle. These can be filled down if you don't need them.
See my other thing: "Strap buckle for loop at end of leash" for more pictures".

print_settings.Notes:: I know I said this before, but all parts with the label "TPU" in their name are intended to be made out of flexible TPU filament.

title: Customizable Utility Belt (please read desc.)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple utility belt designed to be heavily customizable. It can be placed through most sizes of belt loops, or can be worn unsupported by itself. New links can be made easily for a variety of purposes; I included one such example, which is a phone holster. The holster can rotate to the side to allow the phone to be placed in, then can rotate vertically to lock the phone in place so it won't move (see photos). In its current form, it rotates clockwise from its vertical position (so if you wore it on your right hip, you would have to push it forward to allow the phone to come out). The STL file of the phone holster can be mirrored in whatever slicing software you use so that it can rotate the other way, if you want.

I included STL files for direct printing, and STEP files for easier modification of the 3D models.

The fasteners that are intended for use with this belt are #8-32 x 1-1/4" bolts and #8-32 nylon lock nuts (the bolts used in the pictures are 1" long, but I recommend 1-1/4" long bolts because they will fully engage the nylon locking insert of the lock nuts, whereas the 1" long bolts will only partially engage). My bolts are made of brass, but that's only because I like the look of the golden brass color against the black PLA; they can be steel as well.

The phone holster is designed for an HTC One Max, although it wouldn't be too hard to design other holster parts that fit other phone models (I recommend having a screen protector). More info on designing holsters for your own phone is detailed below.

The part called "phone holder tpu insert" will be contacting the screen of the phone, so making it out of TPU is absolutely CRITICAL (because TPU is soft and squishy), or else you risk scratching or even breaking your screen with a harder plastic (this won't need to be redesigned for most new phone holster designs). The second TPU part is intended to be placed at the bottom of the phone holster, so that will need to be redesigned for new phone holster designs. The third TPU part is called "flexible_tpu_link", and it is designed to act as a sort of belt tensioner; since the rigid PLA links don't have much give at all, this link will give the belt some extra "stretchyness" so that it doesn't get really uncomfortable when you go to sit down or bend over. These could also be made of TPE, which is even softer.

One thing to keep in mind when redesigning the phone holster is that when the phone holster is turned to lock the phone in place, the button shaped TPU insert in the belt link that mounts the phone holster will press against the screen of your phone (it is supposed to, so that your phone will stay in place). Therefore, it is essential that you make sure that you put enough distance between where your phone sits in the holster and the little TPU button so that it does not press against your screen too hard (that could make bad things happen, and I don't want any of you to ruin your phones).

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

All parts except for parts with the label "TPU" in their name were originally printed out of PLA. An excellent site for good quality PLA printing settings is: https://www.sd3d.com/pla-settings/

All parts that I printed out of PLA could also be printed with ABS, although some parts may not fit together properly due to the more active thermodynamic nature of ABS; all parts (except TPU parts) were toleranced with the intent of printing them out of PLA. The same goes for Nylon. ABS and Nylon would also be better choices for material due to its high impact strength.

I know I said this before, but all parts with the label "TPU" in their name are intended to be made out of flexible TPU filament.

I got fed up with my Samsung TV remote (marked BN59-01247) rolling around everytime I pressed a button; seems insane to design a remote control with a round bottom.

The foot/stand/holder clips around the remote and provides a base the width of the remote; no rollling about. The foot did slide up and down the remote so I secured it with a bit of thin double-sided tape.

This remote measures 44 mm wide and 22 mm high (excluding the buttons)

Description: https://youtu.be/G9-N-nIqc4g

Torque Capabilities

Please know that i designed this CVT for a demonstration model, it's not intended to be used as an actual transmission

How This Works

  • Watch the video!

Look out!

  • Somehow I lost all of my last changes to this project after I printed it, and I had to go back into the cad model and remake them, I do not have time to reprint the whole thing again, so there is a possibility of clearance issues (or other issues) for the first few people that print this, if you have ANY problems with this model, please leave a comment and I will try to fix them ASAP.
  • Is their anything missing? Let me know!
Hardware Required!
  • 2 Sheetrock screws 1" or 2" long.
  • 4.5mm BB's You Need These BB's
Print settings
  • You need to calibrate your printer to +/- .02 mm on a 20mm calibration cube before you print this or it will not fit and/or work properly, use horizontal expansion to accomplish this if necessary, but often oversized parts are caused by printing speed or worn out nozzle.
  • It is also necessary to level your bed - especially if you have an auto leveling sensor. This one cause me to have to reprint due to compensation that is done after auto leveling.
  • 1.2mm wall thickness and 10% - 30% infill at .2mm layer height.
  • Print everything in the orientation that it's already in (yes print the cam adjustment shaft horizontally)
  • Use supports where necessary, I think I marked everything that needs it but use your own judgement.
  • PRINT ALL THE GEARS SEPARATELY (including the ratchet gear) and slow your printing speed down substantially, otherwise they will come out too rough and will not fit together.
Part Preparation
  • Use a screwdriver (or the cam control shaft) to break the custom support material out of the inside hole of the crankshaft, this is there to help bridging and is only one layer thick.
  • Separate the eccentric components from each other, they should not be attached.
  • The two halves of the eccentric mount have a bearing race around them, its likely that the bearing race might have a small "bump" where the two halves meet due to printing jerk, use an exacto knife to make this bearing race nice and even.
Assembly
  • I plan to make an assembly video sometime soon, but until then, follow these instructions.
  • Assembly order
    1. Assemble all three ratchets onto the output shaft, making sure that the ratchet pawl's are facing the clicker thingy, and the ratchet body's are facing the same way.
    2. Install the crankshaft into the frame. The hex side of the crankshaft should be on the frame left side, then loosely place the three large pushrods (the giant circles) around the crankshaft.
    3. Slide the output shaft with the ratchets into the frame.
    4. Place the other side of the frame onto the machine, and use sheetrock screws to attach it.
    5. Assemble the ratio adjuster gearbox, it's really hard to put together, and if it doesn't spin super freely you will need to reprint with a negative horizontal expansion setting. Ring gears need to be installed so that they are in the order of 1,2
    6. Install the ratio adjuster with large carrier facing towards the frame, align the index marks on the crankshaft and the ring gear, and make sure the small carrier is facing out.
    7. Install the cam control shaft through the entire apparatus, placing the cam gears into each pocket of the crankshaft in order of the marks on them with the marks facing the same direction, rotate the cam control shaft or the cam gears until the shaft slides through them( align the index position marks)
    8. Install the ratio adjustment cover, aligning the notches on the cover to the notches on the ring gear.
    9. At this point, the crank shaft should spin somewhat freely, and the cam gears should rotate at the same speed as the crankshaft assembly, if It does not, the gears are binding somewhere.
    10. Install the two half's of the eccentric mount on the crankshaft in whichever spot you like, making sure to mate the rack of gears up with the cam gear.
    11. Slide the pushrod over the top of the two halves of the eccentric mount and fill the grove up with 4.5mm BB's.
    12. Once the raceway is filled with BB's, remove one or two BB's and then install the small wedge shaped piece into the bearing fill hole, the side with two faces should face out. I used a dab of hot glue to hold this piece in.
    13. Repeat steps 8,9 and 10 for the other two eccentric's making sure not to flip them around (I.E. The build plate side should be on the same side for all three)
    14. Place the wrist pins through the ratchets one at a time, use the eccentric offset adjustment to make the middle ratchet accessible

Other Important Info:

CAD Files??
  • I Included the Fusion 360 Project with this, But the most recent version of this project can be downloaded in lots of different formats from this link: http://a360.co/2IhRLLa
  • Feel free to create your own modifications and parts for this project, and if you do, make sure you create a remix and upload them, I'll link to them and possible create a collection for all of them!
Show Your Work!
  • Make a "make" and show everyone what you made! Everyone will thank you for it!

For More Cool Gearbox Projects, Don't forget Subscribe to Gear Down For What?! https://www.youtube.com/c/GearDownForWhat

Thanks!

title: Utility Clamp Light Screw on Shade

description.text:
This is a decorative pyramid shaped shade that screws directly on to utility clamp lights. I use three of them for my pool table and it looks pretty nice, better than the aluminum reflectors that came with it. You can customize with your own colors - I used regular colored paper, just cut to size and use your favorite glue to secure to the plastic (I used UHU). If you print with white PLA, the whole thing glows - very cool looking!

Only for use with LED bulbs! Other bulbs get hot and might melt the plastic or cause the paper to catch on fire.

Print one top and four panels. The smooth side of the panel faces outward, and it should just snap fit into the top. Use a little bit of hot glue at the bottom of the pyramid panels to join together. Unscrew your aluminum reflector and screw this on.

not 100% my design just edited it so people have a descent copy for free. hope you all enjoy!

Use this clip to store your filament spool and prevent it from unwinding itself. Instead of clipping the filament the the spool itself, this clip is attached to the filament itself. Therefore it can be used with any kind of spool.
The clip was originally designed for filament up to 3mm and is very easy to use. Depending upon the exact diameter the clip will easily slide over the end of the filament (see picture with the blue filament) or it can be put on the end of the filament as a kind of 'cap' (see picture with the yellow & red filament)
If you want to use this clip for smaller diameter filament you can simply scale it down or download the 1,75mm version of it Update V2.1: Modified the STL file:
  • the default orientation of the clip is changed
  • higher resolution stl-file
    • Update clip175-v1.STL : I created a new version of the clip especially for people using 1,75mm filament. Simply download this version for your 1,75mm filament

I printed a batch of 4 of these clips each time I switch the filament on my Ultimaker-2. I used the following settings in Cura to slice it:
Layer height: 0.1mm
Shell thickness: 1mm
Botto/top: 0.8mm
Infill: 0%
Speed: 50 mm/s

title: Eyas X3 Camera top plate & XT30 mount

description.text:
This is a cam mount (runcam micro sized) with integrated antenna holders (which also act as a bit of protection for the camera), as well as an XT30 mount that doubles as a surface to mount a LED strip and/or buzzer to.

Print in TPU/TPE/Ninjaflex. Should need no supports, but you may have to push a drill bit in and out of the antenna tubes a few times to open them up. Antennas can just be pushed in, or fixated with a bit of tape or glue after sliding in.
The camera is slightly high on purpose, with the space below it large enough to install a HMDVR-S micro DVR (with case removed) for onboard recording of the camera signal. It may also fit various micro VTX.

For the XT30 mount, add a bit of hotglue or similar over the exposed contacts. Some superglue will keep the connector from sliding out. Use an M3 screw and nut, and preferably a washer, to hold the XT30 mount onto the rear of the copter.

This frame is an overall very tight fit, but makes up for it in size (112mm for 3" props) and weight (Easy to stay <250g even on 4S).

Soma Cube

Note: this thing is not a complete puzzle, this is just a core

Description

I needed a 8-axis core for my Redi Cube clone. Usually 3D printed cores do not provide enough strenght and tend to crack on layers. I searched for a simple design (at least simple for printing), that is strong enough and also provide a way to tune tensioning. Here it is.

Pros:

  • Uses regular rubik's cube core, screws and springs
  • Easy for printing
  • All springs mechanism is located inside the core. Attached parts require only a space for a nut

Cons:

  • This design does not fix axis orientation - it may slightly move under external force. This may be ok for some puzzles (e.g. Face Turning Octahedron), but Redi Cube gets too loose

Core diameter is 44mm

Materials needed:

  • Standard Rubik's cube Core
  • 6x sets of Screws and Springs
  • 8x M3 12mm screws

Printing and assembly

Print the following number of parts:

  • 6x Cap
  • 6x Cap Base
  • 8x Corner

Cap Base shall be glued to the Cap (this basically is a single part, split to simplify printing). I used Acethone for parts printed in ABS. Use 3mm drill to remove a small membrane in Cap pieces (it was designed to simplificaty printing and avoiding supports)

Use springs when screwing Cap pieces to core

Corner piece of the core is screwed to corresponding puzzle part (Redi Cube Corner or Face Turning Octahedron center piece). No need for springs here. Do not screw parts too tight - it should freely rotate

Corner pieces have protrusions that should fit corresponding gaps in Cap piece. This is done to fix piece position, but allow some elastic movements

Feel free to review my design source in details at https://cad.onshape.com/documents/0c898146eff8a4ab038c2c37/v/965c9b87c16fa7cf4b113b59/e/a97d32a0ffa55f3f443a0366

title: Universal Phone to Camera Tripod Adaptor

description.text:
I looked at a few of the camera to tripod adaptors on here and didn't find any that I particularly liked so I made up my own. :-) This will fit any phone between about 65mm and 115mm and could be easily modified smaller/larger if need be.

My criteria were that it should fit the standard 1/4-20 thread on a tripod without any further adaptors and that it should be easily adjustable (just a rubber band to hold the tension).

I do need to give some credit to TICKTACULAR and his design: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2740498
I lifted the screw thread from his design but found I needed to scale it by 110% to get it to fit my mini tripod that uses a standard 1/4-20 UNC screw. I have included the file for just the screw thread if anyone else wants to use it as a starting point.

title: Double Spinning Linkage Bars, Geometric Construction, Pendulum

description.text:
Double Spinning Linkage Bars, Geometric Construction, Pendulum

An interesting set of three types of linkage bars with double spinning structures—spinning connectors plus grooved joints. By mixing and matching the bars, one can build all sorts of mathematical, physical, or even chemical models. They are flexible, growing in 3D and spinning in many ways. These structures are quite chaotic as you will find!

Each joint is about 35mm in diameter and is 8mm in width. They are pretty sturdy. To connect, just gently snap them together. Because of the double rotational design, it might be hard to separate them once snapped together. Please use a flat-blade screw driver to pry them open slowly.

There are three types— two connectors, one connector, and no connector. A cap is also included. They come in lengths (center to center) of 40mm, 50mm, 60mm, 70mm, 80mm, 90mm, and 100mm.

Please use a resolution less than 0.15mm and an infill greater than 10% for strength.

Have fun and help kids do some math. Thank you for visiting!

title: A-Max Anura Antenna mounts + cam mount

description.text:
I ended up not using this frame, but I did create some parts for it. They're mostly untested, but were checked for fit. Print in TPU.

  • The cam mount is set at 30° if using a camera with 3 mounting holes, and allows the camera to be mounted further forward, since with the original mounting, an angle of more than 20° is not possible. If using just the center hole, you can freely rotate the camera at the angle you want.
  • The XT30 and RC antenna mount requires a drop of superglue to keep the XT30 in place. If you mount a 4in1 ESC, the power cables have to be extremely short, so it may be best to rotated the ESC with the power pins to the front.
  • The FPV antenna mount has a surface to stick a buzzer or LED strip to, and is meant for an IPEX antenna to slide through the hole before being plugged into the VTX. It will keep the antenna slightly angled upwards.

title: Minimal case for ‘3D sound’ USB sound card

description.text:
This is a minimal case for the very cheap ‘3D Sound’ USB soundcards that can typically be found for prices around 1 or 2 Euros or Dollars. These come in an unnecessarily large plastic housing that often makes it impossible to plug other things in neighboring ports, for instance on a Raspberry Pi 3 they block access to two of the other ports.
D4rKiTo already made a smaller case, but I wanted an even smaller one.
The original case on my device was 39×23×12.3 mm. The new one (thinnest model) is 39×18×10 mm, and at the plug end it is only 8 mm thick.

To make the circuit board fit, you will probably need to do some post-processing on the PCB to cut down the pins and solder blobs sticking out from the underside. The easiest way to do this is to (carefully) rub the PCB across sandpaper. The normal model only has 0.75 mm of space under the PCB. The ‘extraSpace’ model offers 0.5 mm extra, hence can do with a bit less post-processing. Of course, this makes it 0.5 mm thicker as well, so if you really need all the space you can get, a little bit of extra effort will be needed so you can use the thinner model.

Tolerances are quite tight. Make sure your printer is well calibrated. In case the print is too sloppy or tight, scaling up/down the whole model by a fraction of a percent might help.

I suspect there are multiple variations on this sound card, and some may have a different PCB design than the one I have, and may not fit inside this casing. You mileage may vary!

(By the way, these sound cards have no special 3D sound capabilities. They are just bog standard USB audio devices with pretty poor sound quality and power handling that is often incapable of driving a decent set of headphones, but for small projects where quality isn't important, they are unbeatable for their price.)

title: Wind turbine, experiment on the effect of the number of rotor blades and their angle of attack on the performance.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have designed this for a school project of my son (Fip NWA, Fachinterne Prüfung NaturWissenschaftlichesArbeiten).
More description will follow (I hope).

For this to work in OpenSCAD, you need the NACA Airfoils library from Parkinbot:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:898554 Many thanks for this library.

You can print it for 2 to 6 rotor blades, and configure also different angles. The rotor blades are mounted with a bayonet joint, and all parts are designed to print without support.

In our case we can say, that the transmission with the belt drive is not needed, respectively has too much friction loss. So take the direct drive, and mount the rotor directly to an engine with a 2 mm shaft.

Up to now I can not say, what is the result of the experiment. How ever, find it out for your own :-)

title: Wire Dispenser - Easy and Stackable - Organizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This time I've designed EASY TO PRINT wire dispenser! There are 2 versions:

  • 5 larger reels (box5 + 5x reel5 + 5x cover) - larger cables
  • 10 smaller reels (box10 + 10x reel10 + 10x cover) - thinner cables

We all got messy cables lying around and this is very nice solution! It's stackable (box is same size regarding of reel number) and very easy to print solution. Just print box and reels, than assemble the reels (I've glued them together) and just wind the cable on the reel. When you have all reels filled up, insert the rod from the side and that's it!

You can use 6mm plastic, wooden, aluminium, brass, steel rod, tube or stick INSTEAD of printing it. I used brass tubes I got laying around. It needs to be around 152mm in length.

There is also top plate inside, that can be printed and used if you got very dusty workplace.

SILICON WIRES I RECOMMEND AVAILABLE WORLDWIDE (higher AWG = thinner wire):

  • 5m RED silicone wire 10-22AWG = https://goo.gl/cS9CJq
  • 5m Black silicone wire 10-22AWG = https://goo.gl/qWd5f9
  • 1m RED + 1m BLACK 8-30AWG Silicone wire = https://goo.gl/trVNzV
  • 1m RED + 1m BLACK silicon wire 12-20AWG = https://goo.gl/harFi8

If you find my design useful, you can tip me with a $ or 2 :)
https://www.paypal.me/JureKorber

Have fun! =)
